issue.title: Move most capabilities out of the `core.Engine` in preparation for removal

repository.name: k6
repository.description: A modern load testing tool, using Go and JavaScript

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
This built on top of https://github.com/grafana/k6/pull/2812 and is the penultimate PR before https://github.com/grafana/k6/issues/1889 :tada: :crossed_fingers: 

It splits off as much of the capabilities of the `Engine` as it's possible to do and keep most of its tests (_mostly_) intact :sweat_smile: Commits should be atomic and it might be easier to review the PR commit by commit. I can even split this into smaller PRs, if needs be, though I think grouping these commits together in one PR and completely removing the `Engine` in another PR makes the most sense.

issue.title: Refactor `lib.Runner` and `js.Runner`

labels.name: evaluation needed
labels.description: proposal needs to be validated or tested before fully implementing it in k6

repository.name: k6
repository.description: A modern load testing tool, using Go and JavaScript

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
Prompted by [this PR comment](https://github.com/grafana/k6/pull/2813/files#r1085128216), I am opening this issue as a gathering place for all of the problems with the current `lib.Runner` interface (and its main `js.Runner` implementation): 
https://github.com/grafana/k6/blob/1d99b0be9194bf9aaf86c070dd0d34604f266abe/lib/runner.go#L41-L85

The biggest issue is probably the name itself. `Runner` is a very poor fit for what is essentially a VU factory.

Another problem is the current API. It is too broad, and the `Runner` it is both a factory for creating new VUs, but also something that can run lifecycle functions like `setup()`, `teardown()` and `handleSummary()` in a transient VU. There is probably no reason these two functionalities to be in the same object. We might not even need yo have dedicated methods for each of these, with the right API... :thinking: 

Another problem is `GetDefaultGroup()`, though it has a dedicated issue for it: https://github.com/grafana/k6/issues/2869

Dealing with archiving and transpiling probably also need to be refactored somewhat (https://github.com/grafana/k6/issues/1048). I am not sure if that will affect the `Runner`, probably yes :thinking:

issue.title: `group` doesn't work with async calls well

labels.name: evaluation needed
labels.description: proposal needs to be validated or tested before fully implementing it in k6

repository.name: k6
repository.description: A modern load testing tool, using Go and JavaScript

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.title: k6.check: Fix returned values when iteration is ending

repository.name: k6
repository.description: A modern load testing tool, using Go and JavaScript

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
Before this check was only returning `false` if it also could emit it, and true otherwise.

This should rarely be a problem as the same context that is being checked here is the one that interrupts the VM - so no code will be able to run after this.

Unfortunately the code checking if it should be emitted is racing with the one that interrupts the VM. So it is possible for the VM to still not be interrupted when a `check` returns a wrong value. It is even possible for more code to be run before the interrupt is actually called.

The code still checks the context as this also updates the internal check structure and we don't want to that if the context is done. The above should be changed with #2869

Fixes #2912

issue.title: Try to use `sobek#AsyncContextTracker` to make group for async code

labels.name: evaluation needed
labels.description: proposal needs to be validated or tested before fully implementing it in k6

repository.name: k6
repository.description: A modern load testing tool, using Go and JavaScript

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
# Why? 

As explained in https://github.com/grafana/k6/issues/2728 `group` doesn't work with async functions (or execution). 

This is not specific to `group` - anything that keeps state has problems with keeping that state in async execution. 

This is more explored in the issue above and in this tc39 [proposal](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-async-context). 

# What? 

As the problem is so generic and was already kind of tried to be fixed for `group` in https://github.com/grafana/k6/pull/2863 the point of this is to have a little bit mroe generic solution akin to the one in the tc39 proposal above.

This is a research task trying to make that possible and then make it possible to implement a `group` like API for async functions. 

Probably after #2869 is also fixed. 

The two issues though are orhogonal.

This can also be though of as continuation of https://github.com/grafana/k6/issues/884

body:
For the record. After an internal discussion, we decided to clean a milestone since the issue was jumping between milestones without completion.

Once we determine which milestone it lands, we set the right one.

issue.title: Refactor group and check to not be tightly coupled

labels.name: breaking change
labels.description: for PRs that need to be mentioned in the breaking changes section of the release notes

repository.name: k6
repository.description: A modern load testing tool, using Go and JavaScript

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
## What?

Group and check were tightly coupled between them and also to the end of test summary and the REST API.

This change the tight coupling is removed. Group and check no longer interact with each other while being run.

In order to keep the same end of test summary and REST API behavior the code makes the same aggregation it used to be but *only* based on the metrics emitted by `check` and `group`.

There are several breaking changes still in it as a bunch of things are no longer useful, and technically not implementable if we want to remove the tight coupling.

The only one that is relevant though is that
`lib.State` no longer has `Group`.

There are 2 extensions using that and both of them use it to use the "magic" that tight `group` and `check` together.

## Why?

The previous code apart from having problems code smell wise, meant that you can't implement this functionality in JS.

Which also means that they act very strangely especially as if you do not look closely it just seems like they set a few tags and emit metrics. 

While working on #2728 it became apparent that it is unlikely we will get a perfect solution and one of the big problems is that you can't even experiment without having to write a fairly complicated async go code.

So this also makes that issue a bit more actionable. And definitely a thing that now people can have not perfect or even 80%, but still workable for them solutions.

## Checklist

If you haven't read the contributing guidelines https://github.com/grafana/k6/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md 
and code of conduct https://github.com/grafana/k6/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md yet, please do so
-->

- [ ] I have added tests for my changes.
- [x] I have run linter locally (`make lint`) and all checks pass.
- [x] I have run tests locally (`make tests`) and all tests pass.
- [x] I have commented on my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas.
<!-- - [ ] Any other relevant item -->
